title: Express Talk: The Myth of the Salamander
hero_caption: Saint-Louis France. Paperweight, about 1845-60. Bequest of Arthur Rubloff.
description:
In the first century AD, the natural philosopher Pliny the Elder noted that salamanders have long been said to thrive in fire, or even to be born from flames. That myth has thrived as an exquisite, unsettling image, notably in the flames of the glassblower’s furnace, as glassworkers adopted the amphibian as a symbol of their own beauty that’s born in fire. Join Woman’s Board Fellow Alice Boone in exploring the myth’s beautiful manifestations in paperweight form.
